title: Language and Literacy: Preschool domain
subject: Head Start Early Learning Outcomes Framework (2015-)

document.title: Head Start Early Learning Outcomes Framework: Ages Birth to Five

8ABC1025308245279A5ED78B3551ACD9.description:
Writes (draws, illustrates) for a variety of
purposes and demonstrates evidence
of many aspects of print conventions,
such as creating a book that moves left
to right.

5554698D7FA348939A34D89E7EB26FF1.description:
Writes first name correctly or close to
correctly.

FA1E877CF3B648849CC62AB01E44F9A0.description:
Attempts to independently write some
words using invented spelling, such as
K for kite.

D103A632F27D46F5A3EF469E045B9F79.description:
Shows an interest in copying simple
words posted in the classroom.

22ECE96DA44D44C88267ACE71145EA28.description:
Creates a variety of written products
that may or may not phonetically relate
to intended messages.

4705090085F04A6F95890CE8FB5AF06B.description:
48 to 60 Months: Progressively uses drawing, scribbling,
letter-like forms, and letters to
intentionally convey meaning. With
support, may use invented spelling
consisting of salient or beginning
sounds, such as L for elevator or B
for bug.

136FE55D48794F23B3266758B5A33FC0.description:
36 to 48 Months: Engages in writing activities that
consist largely of drawing and
scribbling. Begins to convey meaning.
With modeling and support, writes
some letter-like forms and letters.

172EBD5C3C5547F090D93E90D9BD8087.description: Child writes for a variety of purposes using increasingly sophisticated marks.

9AD1A92BDB594351B72F26201007BB0D.description:
Provides a summary of a story, highlighting
a number of the key ideas in the story
and how they relate.

BDBB51FC7E224149B49ED1920301FCE7.description:
Answers increasingly complex
inferential questions that require making
predictions based on multiple pieces
of information from the story; inferring
characters’ feelings or intentions; or
providing evaluations of judgments that
are grounded in the text.

7DBE84A4EDB248F2B7D6E9CF31F804D4.description:
Answers questions about details of a story
with increasingly specific information,
such as when asked “Who was Mary?”
responds “She was the girl who was
riding the horse and then got hurt.”

FEB9C69BEA664BF4A0F6EA95684B041E.description:
48 to 60 Months: With support, provides basic answers
to specific questions about details
of a story, such as who, what, when,
or where. With support, can answer
inferential questions about stories,
such as predictions or how/why
something is happening in a particular
moment.

36F98E209541497AB329074307AB5E6F.description:
36 to 48 Months: Can answer basic questions about
likes or dislikes in a book or story. Asks
and answers questions about main
characters or events in a familiar story.
With modeling and support, makes
predictions about events that might
happen next.

44EE94941787499C90926BAF8E5A8B6E.description: Child asks and answers questions about a book that was read aloud.

87E547EB93674C37B397C45758CCC3AB.description:
Identifies characters and main events in
books and stories.

D860E44730CA4D88B23B8779015F2F86.description:
Tells fictional or personal stories using
a sequence of at least 2–3 connected
events.

50A9D24A14D7426F9EEDE04DFF0481E3.description:
Re-tells or acts out a story that was
read, putting events in the appropriate
sequence, and demonstrating more
sophisticated understanding of how
events relate, such as cause and effect
relationships.

015CA02FB480410BAA86F50361867ADF.description:
48 to 60 Months: Retells 2–3 key events from a wellknown story, typically in the right
temporal order and using some simple
sequencing terms, such as first …
and then.

C137B789F34640988F20B14B7D168D85.description:
36 to 48 Months: With support, may be able to tell one or
two key events from a story or may act
out a story with pictures or props.

DB883B87C95241F492121FC1EC0D4635.description: Child demonstrates an understanding of narrative structure through storytelling/re-telling.

FFDB1246F0AE44A7A2B8BF810890995B.description:
Knows the sounds associated with
several letters.

551A376E95764F33B4321A685632D66E.description:
48 to 60 Months: Recognizes and names at least half of
the letters in the alphabet, including
letters in own name (first name and last
name), as well as letters encountered
often in the environment. Produces the
sound of many recognized letters.

DA1B09CC75374CBB95192114734819BA.description:
36 to 48 Months: Shows an awareness of alphabet
letters, such as singing the ABC song,
recognizing letters from one’s name,
or naming some letters that are
encountered often.

A98E26183FE545999A98D29563977C3B.description: Child identifies letters of the alphabet and produces correct sounds associated with letters.

7C1F9068B54F4A408C4B2A26C6E338D3.description:
Identifies book parts and features, such
as the front, back, title, and author.

D64E59E058774E3388A14830B49B07F8.description:
Begins to point to single-syllable words
while reading simple, memorized texts.

2EE60008B7804C998D381477282AD58D.description:
Understands that written words are
made up of a group of individual letters.

98E85159EB6C43349A19F74157F1E11F.description:
Understands that print is organized
differently for different purposes, such
as a note, list, or storybook.

BAB6A1811DBC41329E685EF00FE6D482.description:
48 to 60 Months: Begins to demonstrate an understanding
of the connection between speech and
print. Shows a growing awareness that
print is a system that has rules and
conventions, such as holding a book
correctly or following a book left to right.

4A81EC0047054DC68FAAEC5DABD8A1B4.description:
36 to 48 Months: Distinguishes print from pictures and
shows an understanding that print is
something meaningful, such as asking
an adult “What does this say?” or
“Read this.”

BCA607D12481419292D8B4027F8AD2D4.description:
Child demonstrates an understanding of how print is used (functions of print) and the rules that
govern how print works (conventions of print).

33B53E2ACA8A4E248C55769B1AFDE64F.description:
Provides a word that fits with a group
of words sharing an initial sound, with
adult support, such as “Sock, Sara, and
song all start with the /s/ sound. What
else starts with the /s/ sound?”

7CB2D581E4BC4570B59FE156623D8D85.description:
Produces the beginning sound in a
spoken word, such as “Dog begins with
/d/.”

314A0A01FDEE459F9AE11CAB70355A16.description:
Provides one or more words that rhyme
with a single given target, such as “What
rhymes with log?”

5824E9A4AC6E4DB596F335260FA901D5.description:
48 to 60 Months: Demonstrates rhyme recognition, such
as identifying which words rhyme
from a group of three: hat, cat, log.
Recognizes phonemic changes in
words, such as noticing the problem
with “Old McDonald had a charm.” Is
able to count syllables and understand
sounds in spoken words.

3FDC6E32CFA14B12B667999681FF819D.description:
36 to 48 Months: Shows rote imitation and enjoyment of
rhyme and alliteration. With support,
distinguishes when two words rhyme
and when two words begin with the
same sound.

0DD0B9E218AA49E4B6A3DD26A3CC0CF1.description: Child demonstrates awareness that spoken language is composed of smaller segments of sound.

0D7E4A46A26E4247928FD2D7251C3B97.description:
Shows an ability to distinguish similar
words, such as “I don’t like it, I love it!”
or “It’s more than tall, it’s gigantic” or
“It’s so cold, it’s frosty.”

03E42EEC172C4599A5EAAC651EBE15EF.description:
Identifies key common antonyms, such
as black/white or up/down. Identifies
1–2 synonyms for very familiar words,
such as glad or happy.

7B1B9A11A2E6477BA4824CC02A6C1785.description:
Identifies shared characteristics among
people, places, things, or actions, such
as identifying that both cats and dogs
are furry and have four legs.

E357474F032249ACBF49FCC818FF567D.description:
Discusses new words in relation to
known words and word categories, such
as “It fell to the bottom when it sank” or
“When you hop it’s like jumping on one
leg” or “The bear and fox are both wild
animals.”

063B74D098394BBD93349A918A30CC8B.description:
Categorizes words or objects, such as
sorting a hard hat, machines, and tools
into the construction group, or giving
many examples of farm animals.

EBE1DEEB9C754B81A04AF2860B5B12C5.description:
48 to 60 Months: Demonstrates an increasingly
sophisticated understanding of words
and word categories with support,
such as listing multiple examples of
a familiar category or identifying a
synonym or antonym.

2BDD605D316840368C3131A1296426DD.description:
36 to 48 Months: Typically uses known words in the
correct context and, with support,
shows an emerging understanding
of how words are related to broader
categories, such as sorting things by
color.

8F38A6EFD29843C193DC131D8E53B7D7.description: Child shows understanding of word categories and relationships among words.

328B329D212F43C38745A298F92C0D79.description:
With support, forms guesses about the
meaning of new words from context
clues.

70216DA947CA459F956F99711771BC7A.description:
With multiple exposures, uses new
domain-specific vocabulary during
activities, such as using the word
“cocoon” when learning about the lifecycle of caterpillars, or “cylinder” when
learning about 3-D shapes.

0A99DF499A514B31BC5452086E58E311.description:
Shows recognition of and/or familiarity
with key domain-specific words heard
during reading or discussions.

96BF42403C414E2384328A6FFEE99066.description:
Demonstrates the use of multiple (2–3)
new words or signs a day during play
and other activities.

82C812B5765D482182795A1AFF4C2323.description:
48 to 60 Months: Shows a steady increase in vocabulary
through the acquisition of words with
increasing specificity and variety.
Shows repetition of new words offered
by adults and may ask about the
meaning of unfamiliar words.

F761AE28D47D48209EC35BCA4DDAA027.description:
36 to 48 Months: Shows a rapid increase in acquisition
of new vocabulary words that describe
actions, emotions, things, or ideas that
are meaningful within the everyday
environment. Uses new vocabulary
words to describe relations among
things or ideas. Shows repetition of
new words offered by adults.

50996E36C13040C1994505D04D7A06B1.description: Child understands and uses a wide variety of words for a variety of purposes.

EFAFC7DFE0A44F38BB1A84E090B9B162.description:
Can produce and organize multiple
sentences on a topic, such as giving
directions or telling a story, including
information about the past or present
or things not physically present, and
answer a variety of question types.

3B9A3609491F43E08C3218AE724B08A1.description:
Typically, uses complete sentences
of more than 5 words with complex
structures, such as sentences involving
sequence and causal relations.

09E9C8051FF04170AE56BF647149C767.description:
Communicates clearly enough to be
understood by adults across a range
of situations. Pronunciation errors and
grammatical errors are isolated and
infrequent. Shows proficiency with
prepositions, regular/irregular past
tense, possessives, and noun-verb
agreement.

5BED838788AB4A649C636BC86D24C66A.description:
48 to 60 Months: Communicates clearly enough
to be understood by familiar and
unfamiliar adults, but may make
some pronunciation errors and some
isolated grammatical errors. Uses
longer sentences, as well as sentences
that are slightly more complex, such
as “I need a pencil because this one
broke.” Can offer multiple pieces of
information on a topic with increasing
independence and answer simple
questions.

B09AB9B7E8BB4160902C071D8857CDF2.description:
36 to 48 Months: Communicates clearly enough to be
understood by familiar adults, but
may make some pronunciation and
grammatical errors. Typically uses
3–5 word phrases/sentences when
communicating. With some prompting,
can offer multiple (2–3) pieces of
information on a single topic.

04806A1345B249A9A0839B3BE682EB3A.description: Child expresses self in increasingly long, detailed, and sophisticated ways.

127CD7DED1274F5C99170592F8C78961.description:
With increasing independence, matches
the tone and volume of expression to
the content and social situation, such as
by using a whisper to tell a secret.

B5F8678B3C2E4E778666402634A97307.description:
Maintains multi-turn conversations
with adults, other children, and
within larger groups by responding in
increasingly sophisticated ways, such
as asking related questions or
expressing agreement.

B3E532C01A774AB9AB2DF2205E2C416C.description:
48 to 60 Months: Maintains multi-turn conversations
with adults or other children by being
responsive to the conversational
partner in a variety of ways, such as
by asking a question. With increasing
independence, varies tone and volume
of expression to match the social
situation.

5BFEEFF473A64BDA8621A3A3E4834CBE.description:
36 to 48 Months: Engages in conversations with adults,
other children, or within the group
setting lasting 2–3 conversational
turns, and, with support, will
sometimes use appropriate tone and
volume for different situations.

B264E16282D548099627763FE5D88808.description: Child understands, follows, and uses appropriate social and conversational rules.

A3C58C9E33B2461C8DB49154F61CF2D9.description:
Children who are DLLs may switch
between their languages.

7DD22864474B43958A472799B2747455.description:
Uses language, spoken or sign, to
clarify a word or statement when
misunderstood.

CACFF950C00B4612B8318D19CE626449.description:
Usually provides sufficient detail in order
to get needs met, such as explaining a
point of difficulty in a task or sharing a
request from home with the teacher.

BABC2E9D065647FBB9974B585F628E85.description:
48 to 60 Months: Uses language, spoken or sign, for a
variety of purposes and can typically
provide sufficient detail in order to get
needs met from a variety of adults.

29BE26C46ABF4A00BC2BFC239BDCD6C3.description:
36 to 48 Months: Uses language, spoken or sign, for
different purposes and is sometimes
able to provide sufficient detail to get
needs met from a variety of adults.

B83C4017CCFF4156A4FEFBE72FE13AD5.description: Child varies the amount of information provided to meet the demands of the situation.

B211705245444B5881390269B65B3E43.description:
Shows understanding, such as nodding
or gestures, in response to the content of
books read aloud, stories that are told, or
lengthy explanations given on a topic. Children who are DLLs may demonstrate more
complex communication and language in
their home language than in English.

CF0DE43EACD848338B217030E9B2884D.description:
Shows an understanding of talk related
to the past or future.

B7C8CD7251A74A71B54B7F621F4A4519.description:
Shows understanding of a variety of
sentence types, such as multi-clause,
cause-effect, sequential order, or if-then.

7A7DCA47AD00437F84B6D69D7703EA3E.description:
Demonstrates understanding of a variety
of question types, such as “Yes/No?”
or “Who/What/When/Where?” or “How/
Why?”

231679D33FCE40C8AAE01D02935A1ECD.description:
Shows an ability to recall (in order)
multiple step directions.

962E9FBA8287480183C24CD727F6AD89.description:
48 to 60 Months: Shows an understanding of complex
statements, questions, and stories
containing multiple phrases and ideas,
and responds appropriately.

6F5B9E30F2A3463897FCFFFE23FB8047.description:
36 to 48 Months: Understands and responds (verbally
and non-verbally) to increasingly
longer sentences, simple questions,
and simple stories.

1A7CB34CCBD243DD857662863E52CAF5.description: Child understands and responds to increasingly complex communication and language from others.

DB1AFBE321CF4998B419043579618033.description:
Shows ongoing connection to a
conversation, group discussion, or
presentation.

0E9DD7CE8D8F489B9BFDF7E6E41BACB6.description:
Uses verbal and non-verbal signals
appropriately to acknowledge the
comments or questions of others.

DC9BF376FC3343CABBEC11156FEDD03C.description:
48 to 60 Months: Shows acknowledgment of complex
comments or questions. Is able to
attend to longer, multi-turn conversations,
either spoken or signed.

3CA2735951EA406280043714E7A73B1D.description:
36 to 48 Months: Shows acknowledgment of comments
or questions and is able to attend to
conversations, either spoken or signed.

7DB174E838114EB688EB4F84D1DDF048.description: Child attends to communication and language from others.
